summary: This document is internal email correspondence from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) regarding FOIA and Touhy requests related to Jeffrey Epstein. It discusses the New York Times filing a FOIA complaint against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and establishes procedures for handling requests from civil plaintiffs/victims, designating a point person and outlining the legal requirements for such requests.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney representing plaintiffs/victims in civil litigation related to Jeffrey Epstein; the email states the sender will inform Kaplan that they can expect to hear from the Civil Division regarding Touhy request procedures.

events.title: NY Times Files FOIA Complaint Against BOP
events.description: The New York Times files a FOIA complaint challenging the Bureau of Prisons' response (or lack thereof) to the Times's FOIA requests for records related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: DOJ Answer Deadline for FOIA Complaint
events.description: The Department of Justice's answer date for the New York Times FOIA complaint is set for March 4, 2020.

keyFacts: The New York Times filed a FOIA lawsuit against the Bureau of Prisons for failing to adequately respond to requests for Jeffrey Epstein-related records.

The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York established a coordinated process to handle Touhy requests (for testimony or documents) from civil plaintiffs and victims in Epstein-related litigation.

The office designated a specific Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) as the point of contact for these external requests to maintain consistency and separate the communication from criminal AUSAs who may be dealing with the same individuals as victim-witnesses.

The correspondence includes detailed draft language explaining the stringent Touhy regulations that govern the disclosure of information obtained during official duties, including law enforcement and investigatory privileges.
The document reveals ongoing civil litigation by alleged victims of Jeffrey Epstein seeking information from the government, indicating parallel legal proceedings alongside any criminal matters.
